properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected beginning Tuesday. Locations: Rigolet to Nain and the Eagle River area. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm by Wednesday morning with additional amounts possible on Wednesday. Time span: overnight tonight through Wednesday. Remarks: snow is forecast to spread across Labrador overnight tonight. Snow will continue until Thursday morning before tapering off. In addition, strong northerly winds could result in blowing snow over exposed area Tuesday night into Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-15T19:13:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T03:14:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3208143378.2020
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity, Nain and vicinity, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long duration snowfall continuing into Wednesday night. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm today into Wednesday, with additional amounts possible Wednesday night. Locations: Rigolet and vicinity. Time span: today and Wednesday. Remarks: Snow will increase in intensity this morning. Strong northwesterly winds tonight and Wednesday will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow over exposed areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values near -45 expected early this morning. Clear skies and moderate winds under a very cold air mass have allowed temperatures to drop into the low minus thirties overnight. Associated wind chill values near -45 are expected in the region. Conditions will improve by morning as the sun rises, however similar conditions are expected Tuesday night as well. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T01:17:28-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very cold wind chills expected. With temperatures near minus 40, wind chill values will be near minus 50 at times tonight and Tuesday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. Lake effect snow continues to affect the region this morning. Further accumulations of up to 5 cm and low visibility due to heavy falling snow are expected, including along portions of Highway 400. Travel may be hazardous due to partially snow-covered roadways and periods of sudden low visibilities in heavier snow. Conditions should improve by this afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall may occur on Thursday. Locations: southern Nova Scotia. Time span: Beginning Thursday morning and ending late Thursday evening. Remarks: There is considerable uncertainty as to the amount of snowfall these regions will receive. However, current indications are that 15 centimetres of snowfall or more may fall before the snow ends late Thursday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: This morning, visibilities will be poor and near zero at times in snow and blowing snow. These poor weather conditions will continue until Wednesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T01:52:10-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected today, then higher than normal water levels mid-week. Locations: northeastern Newfoundland. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Remarks: Snow will continue today, mixing with rain at times this morning. The snow is forecast to taper off over most areas tonight. Higher than normal water levels are likely during the high tide of Wednesday morning and possible again on Thursday morning due to a combination of storm surge and large waves. At this time, the chance of any significant coastal flooding remains low. However, a change in atmospheric conditions could result in the need for a storm surge warning for coastal areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-16T00:46:15-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Stormy weather expected mid week. Locations: Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm over eastern Newfoundland. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm over central Newfoundland. Time span: Tuesday and Wednesday. Remarks: Wind warnings have been issued along the coast from Terra Nova to St. John's for westerly gusts to 100 km/h. While elsewhere will generally see westerly winds gusting to 80 km/h, there is a possibility the wind warnings may need to be expanded to Bay of Exploits and Bonavista North. Higher than normal water levels are possible during the high tides of Wednesday morning and Thursday morning due to a combination of storm surge and large waves. At this time, the chance of any significant coastal flooding remains low. However, a change in atmospheric conditions could result in the need for a storm surge warning for coastal areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2020-12-14. Higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected near the coast during the concerned period. An intense low pressure system near Newfoundland will cause very strong to high winds over the regions listed below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high tidal range may produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near these localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern standard time): Kamouraska - Rivière-du-Loup - Trois-Pistoles: 2020-12-15, from 01:00 PM to 04:30 PM. Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2020-12-15, from 12:30 PM to 04:00 PM. Matane: 2020-12-15, from 12:30 PM to 04:00 PM. Sainte-Anne-des-Monts - Grande-Vallée: 2020-12-15, from 12:00 PM to 03:30 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-15T23:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T09:19:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1407617128.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, blowing snow and strong winds expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland. Time span: this morning to Wednesday afternoon or evening. Remarks: Snow will develop this morning and is expected to become heavy at times this afternoon. As temperatures fall below freezing this evening, snow will combine with strong winds to reduce visibility in blowing snow. Occasional to frequent whiteout conditions are likely, especially over exposed areas where blowing snow will be more intense. Strongest wind gusts will occur over the Port au Port Peninsula and areas south to Channel-Port aux Basques. Winds will begin to weaken on Wednesday morning. Conditions will begin to improve for some areas on Wednesday afternoon as snow changes to flurries, which will eventually taper off overnight on Wednesday night. Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-16T00:42:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T08:43:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4035673546.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall is expected today. Locations: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Additional snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Highest accumulations are expected over inland areas. Temperatures will be around the freezing mark along the coast, which could cause some melting to occur, resulting in reduced accumulations. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-16T01:02:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T09:03:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0868772313.2020
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 35 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: today into Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow will become heavy, at times, Wednesday morning. Strong northwesterly winds and falling temperatures on Wednesday, will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve Wednesday night. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-16T01:02:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T09:03:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1126066792.2020
Area: Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries, snowsqualls, and blowing snow are expected to develop this morning. Total snowfall: in excess of 30 centimetres by Wednesday evening. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: this morning and continuing until late Wednesday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T00:27:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T08:28:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1638320259.2020
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions are expected to develop this morning, with winds gusting between 80 and 90 km/h. The strongest winds will occur this evening. Winds will weaken after midnight tonight, allowing the visibility to improve and the blizzard conditions to end. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T01:31:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T09:32:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4059259806.2020
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An Arctic air mass combined with moderate winds are resulting in wind chill values near minus 38 over Northwestern Quebec early this morning. These extreme wind chills will return overnight tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T01:40:34-00:00
